description: An assembly error in which a genomic segment from the true species isolate is absent, causing reads to align only partially around the missing region, producing overhangs in the read alignments.
Cumulative of size of regions with no alignment coverage.
Size of the contig in nucleotides.
The value would have been calculated by taking the total no. of reads that map to the contig divided by the contig length.
Usually zero and means no coverage of gaps.
The count/number of continuously covered regions separated by gaps in the sequence.
The count/number of non-covered regions in the sequence.
The percent of the assembly length that is covered by alignments.
The percent of the assembly length that is not covered at all.
Weighted average length of the contig.
Minimum number of contigs that cover 90% of the assembly.
90% weighted percentile: 90% of the nucleotides in the assembly will be in a contig this length or longer.
95% weighted percentile: 95% of the nucleotides in the assembly will be in a contig this length or longer.
Minimum number of contigs that cover 95% of the assembly.
The average phred score for this assembly.
Weighted average mutation frequency.
Weighted average indel frequency.
Weighted average mutation frequency for mutations with frequencies above 50 percent.
Weighted average indel frequency for indels with frequencies above 50 percent.
How heavy the left side versus right side are alignments in this position. Tells that your reference sequence is not fully representative of your isolate, but is one of them.
Averaged weighted length of read alignments.
Average entropy across the reference profile.
Reads per kilobase per million mapped reads.
Number of reads that are unaligned to the common reference genome
Number of reads that aligned to the common reference genome.
Total number of chromosomes in the genome assembly.
Resource that the fasta files are derived from in the form of a URI/static URL.
GC content of the assembly as a percent.
The accession assigned to a genome assembly generated by the FDA Argos Team.
The number of nucleotide bases in a sequence that align to a specific locus in a reference genome. Coverage = (read count * read length ) / total genome size.
Number of genes per organism.
Number of segments in genome.
The section of an organisms genome undergoing analysis (i.e. the gene, segment, chromosome, contig, etc.).
Weighted median: 50% of the nucleotides in the assembly will be in a contig this length or longer.
75% weighted percentile: 75% of the nucleotides in the assembly will be in a contig this length or longer.
Minimum number of contigs that cover 50% of the assembly.
Minimum number of contigs that cover 75% of the assembly.

Haploid, haploid-with-alt-loci (a haploid assembly with alternative loci, for example as provided by the Genome Reference Consortium for the human genome), diploid, unresolved diploid, or alternate pseudohaplotype. See the NCBI Assembly Data Model for a definition of these terms.
The highest level of assembly for any object in the assembly.
Total length of the assembly.
The number of reads that did not align to the reference as a percentage.
Species identification method.
BioCompute Object identifier.
Reflective of the Data Dictionary version currently applied to the dataset.
The platform used to conduct the analysis.
Unique identifier of archive containing data and analyses. Examples include HIVEPack or Research Object (RO).
Name of the expected organism. Should correspond to a NCBI Taxonomy node.
Scientific name for any taxon below the rank of species, i.e. an infraspecific taxon or infraspecies.
The complete taxonomic lineage for the taxonomic node indicated.
Assembly DB identifier (Example: NCBI assembly accession).
NCBI taxonomy identifier of the organism.
The natural host to the organism from which the sample was obtained.
Sample name in source database.
Identification or description of the specific individual from which this sample was obtained.
Name of persons or institute who collected the sample.

The date on which the sample was collected; date/time ranges are supported by providing two dates from among the supported value formats, delimited by a forward-slash character; collection times are supported by adding "T", then the hour and minute after the date, and must be in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC).
Geographical origin of the sample; use the appropriate name from this list http://www.insdc.org/documents/country-qualifier-vocabulary .
Describes the physical, environmental and/or local geographical source of the biological sample from which the sample was derived.
The geographical coordinates of the location where the sample was collected.

Name of source institute and unique culture identifier. See the description for the proper format and list of allowed institutes, http://www.insdc.org/controlled-vocabulary-culturecollection-qualifier .
Age of host at the time of sampling.
Additional information not included in other defined vocabulary fields.
Name of relevant disease, e.g. Salmonella gastroenteritis. Controlled vocabulary, http://bioportal.bioontology.org/ontologies/1009 or http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/mesh .
Final outcome of disease, e.g., death, chronic disease, recovery.
Stage of disease at the time of sampling.
Information regarding health state of the individual sampled at the time of sampling.
Gender or physical sex of the host.
Microbial or eukaryotic strain name.
NCBI BioProject DB ID. A BioProject is a collection of biological data for a single initiative, originating from a single organization or from a consortium.
NCBI BioSample identifier.
The isolate classifer.
Nonredundant protein records always represent one exact sequence that has been observed once or many times in different strains or species.
Internally developed scores used to evaluate the quality and / or quantity of the information present for a particular entry. Scoring criteria may vary per core data set.
Internally developed scores used to evaluate the quality and / or quantity of the information present for a particular entry. Scoring criteria may vary per core data set.
The species/subspecies subgroup to which the sample belongs.
Internally developed scores used to evaluate the quality and / or quantity of the information present for a particular entry. Scoring criteria may vary per core data set.
Internally developed scores used to evaluate the quality and / or quantity of the information present for a particular entry. Scoring criteria may vary per core data set.
Position of interest within the proteome from UniProt.
The UniProt accession number.
Position of interest within the proteome from RefSeq.
The RefSeq protein accession.
The mutated amino acid at position of interest.
The name of the protein or gene product.
The class of the drug resistance target.
The description term used to identify the type of drug or antibiotic resistance conferred in the output of the HIVE DRM pipeline classified by drug type.
The formula used to call the mutation from the table for the HIVE Drug Resistance Pipeline.
The genomic accession of the organism.
The UniProt proteome ID.
The reference PMID for the publication source.
Internally determined as 'concensus reference organism' used as a standard while building and testing Argos QC pipelines.
Isolate accession for each pathogen genome.
Notes describing why SRR was analyzed.
Lab group that ran ngs computation.
Denotes if SRR has been published on argosdb.
The total count of all nucleotides with Ns included.
The total count of all nucleotides.
Name of the representative organism. Should correspond to a NCBI Taxonomy node.
This accession number is a unique identifier assigned to a record in sequence databases such as RefSeq (NCBI).
UniProt accession number assigned to the associated representative genome.
Count of the most identical repeated read.
Standard deviation of the phred score of nucleotides of all reads.
Number of reads.
Percent of a's in the fastq files.
Percent of c's in the fastq files.
Percent of g's in the fastq files.
Percent of t's in the fastq files.
Percent of n's in the fastq files.
Name of instrument used for NGS.

Strategy/method used to generate the NGS. Controlled vocabulary consisting of the following terms: WGA, WGS, WXS, RNA-Seq, miRNA-Seq, WCS CLONE, POOLCLONE, AMPLICON, CLONE, END FINISHING, ChIP-Seq, MNase-Seq, DNase-Hypersensitivity, Bisulfite-Seq, Tn-Seq, EST FL-cDNA, CTS, MRE-Seq, MeDIP-Seq, MBD-Seq, Synthetic-Long-Read, and OTHER.
GC content of the individual fastq files in ngsQC.
Average quality (in phred score) of sequences in a FASTQ read file.
Length (in base pairs) of the shortest sequence(s) in a FASTA/FASTQ read file.
Count of positions the quality of which is significantly different (extremely low or high).
Number of unique reads that are not identical to other reads.
Average length of sequences in a FASTA/FASTQ read file.
Length (in base pairs) of longest sequence(s) present in a FASTA/FASTQ read file.
A list containing the different types of DNA sequences, including Standard, Vertebrate Mitochondrial, Yeast Mitochondrial, etc. From NCBI Taxonomy.
The relative frequency of sequences that are protein coding selected for one relevant species.
The relative frequency of sequences that are not protein coding for each DNA sequence type.
The percentile of complex sequences as computed through Shannons entropy on a sliding window
The percentile of non-complex (repetitive) sequences as computed through Shannons entropy on a sliding window
The average cumulative quality score of adenine in the NGS.
The average cumulative quality score of thiamine in the NGS.
The average cumulative quality score of guanine in the NGS.
The average cumulative quality score of cytosine in the NGS.
The average cumulative quality score of n in the NGS.
Number of n's in the fastq files.
The total count of adenines in the NGS.
The total count of cytosines in the NGS.
The total count of guanines in the NGS.
The total count of thymine in the NGS.
Database identifier assigned by repository and linked to GenBank or other repository.
Individual name of the fastq file involved in ngsQC or siteQC, or that is connected to a genome assembly id and subsequence fasta files in assemblyQC (i.e. SRR10971381_1.fastq).
Resource that the fastq files are derived from (i.e. SRA) in the form of a URI/static URL.

Source of genomic information in the file. From an SRA controlled vocabulary: GENOMIC: [Genomic DNA (includes PCR products from genomic DNA)], TRANSCRIPTOMIC: [Transcription products or non-genomic DNA (EST, cDNA, RT-PCR, screened libraries)], METAGENOMIC : [Mixed material from metagenome], METATRANSCRIPTOMIC: [Transcription products from community targets], SYNTHETIC: [Synthetic DNA], VIRAL RNA: [Viral RNA], OTHER:[Other, unspecified, or unknown library source material (please include additional info in the design description)].
Start position for this feature in the genome file.
End position for this feature in the genome file.
Start position for this feature in the proteome file.
End position for this feature in the proteome file.
Tags associated with this feature. Can be coverage, quality, entropy, mutations, indels, tails, disbalance, anisotropy, and/or partiality.
Values for the tag associated with this feature.
Nucleotide at the position of interest in wild-type sample.
Nucleotide at the position of interest in the alternate sample.
Codon at the position of interest in wild type sample.
Codon at the position of interest in the alternate sample.
Amino acid at position of interest in alternate sample.
Explanation or justification for analysis of this specific site.
Number of unique reads that include a specific nucleotide.
Frequency of a specific nucleotide variation with respect to the number of occurrences of the specific variation.
Correct codon reading frame at site.
Protein accession from UniProt.
Internally developed scores are used to evaluate the quality and / or quantity of the information present for a particular entry. Scoring criteria may vary per core data set.
Count of major mutations.
Count of insertions or deletions.
Amino acid at position of interest in wild type sample.
